comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Irmgard von Rottenthal seems to have been a dancer associated with the Metropolitan Opera, and described as performing and arranging dances in the manner of Isadora Duncan.  The sign up there might be the beginning of "Byzantine" or "Byzantium."

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: NYT of 2/21/1914 indicates that she danced in the opening feature of a pageant at the Hotel Astor -- the Dance of the Dark Ages. The next section of the program (all focused on Venice) was about the Byzantine period. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03E0DF163AE633A...

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Thank you to all for research into this interesting event! We will add more details when we update the descriptive information.

comment.author: 90027340@N05
comment._content: Mrs. Magnus W. Alexander, née Irmgard von Rottenthal was present at the dinner of the Chambre de Commerce International, seated at the Table d'Honneur, left side, on July 10, 1929.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: www.myheritage.co.il/person-1001412_139162841_139162841/i... through Google translation yields: Irmgard Alexander (born Von Rottenthal) Born: December 10, 1884 Location: Moslavina (Croatia) Died: 1979 (at age ~ 95) Location: USA and Magnus W. Alexander Born: February 17, 1870 Location: New York Died: September 10, 1932 (age 62) These dates match en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Magnus_W._Alexander, but the page does not mention a wife. www.myheritage.co.il/person-1000086_139162841_139162841/m... suggests that they married in 1927.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Obituary for Magnus Washington Alexander in NYT of September 12, 1932 select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F00F12FE38551373... says that he married "in 1927, Irmgard von Rothenthal." Notice alternative spelling. They had a son, Herbert Henry.
